reviews.review_msg: No Comments
Very inspirational
One of the best profs at SFU. Very well experienced and approachable.
Very passionate and well experienced

Decent lecturer. She's a bit disorganized and her grading scheme is pretty unclear so communication is key during and outside of class. The curve is tight till the final exam which is worth 30%. Comprehensive review of all the slides and outside research of emerging technology is important for the final.
A very good prof
Funny Prof, very professional.

He can explain course content sufficiently, but was extremely slow with giving feedback on assignments. By the end of the semester we only had grades from week 4 returned to us. The amount of work assigned for a 3 credit class was also absurd and the textbook readings are completely useless. He also had a condescending attitude at times.

Anthony runs the course like a boot camp with weekly memos - in a good way! The weekly memos really help drill in the concepts by making you take a first stab at understanding it before class and having them clarified in class discussions.
Unclear grading for the assignments and group projects.

Although his lectures are dry and barely responds via email, he's very open to answering your questions and providing more detail to assignments before and after class time. 

I think he also works full time outside of lecturing at night so it's understandable if he isn't as responsive during the day.

Even though I saw these reviews, I decided to take a chance because I thought it wouldn't be as bad as people say it is. I was wrong. The professor is extremely unclear on his requirements for ALL assignments and group work, and the lectures are not engaging at all. Avoid him if you can.
professor refuses to help student out, puts in minimal effort, and assignment/midterm are extremely unclear

At the end of the semester, we have a 20 group paper. The issue is that he mentions it maybe once or twice in class very briefly, gives no help at all, doesn't bring it up for the rest of the semester and barely gives any criteria for it except that it's 20 pages, then just expects it done.

His homework assignments are terrible. We have to do 2 case memos this term but the instructions for each are incredibly unclear. He wants us to find an issue with the company and find resolutions but the articles he gives us already answered that for us. It basically just makes you just rewrite the article in your own words and wastes time.

Wow, unreal class experience, worst in my SFU career. Lectures are super dry, expects participation when no opportunities are given, doesnt mark assignments till end of semester, assignments/projects are too open ended, midterm was unfair and disagreed with slides. SFU spends $ on the gondola, spend on good profs instead!
Hard to find something good to say about this prof, lectures put you to bed, asks for participation but doesn't stop talking, takes weeks to respond to emails, and lacks teaching skills.
Boring subject with a boring professor. I wouldn't take this class again.

Irshad grades a portion of the class based on participation but he does not give the class a lot of opportunities to participate. He also gets upset when nobody participates. Instructions for assignments are vague
Irshad is extremely knowledgable, but he lacks teaching skills. He struggles to explain basic concepts in lecture and the notes that he provides do nothing but confuse students.

Walked into this class with no knowledge of IT. Walked out with no useful knowledge of IT. Didn't learn a single thing from the professor. His classes involve making students prepare for presentations every single class and just watches us present. Might as well google and youtube about IT and teach yourself because that's what the class is.

The worst professor Ive had at SFU. Irshad was unorganized, not prepared for class, didnt lecture. Assignments were ambiguous, grading was more ambiguous, seemed random and emotional. Kept changing the weights of assignments and the syllabus throughout the term. Graded all 5 presentations, midterm, individual paper, group paper after the term

Despite doing well, this was the most difficult course of my undergrad due to how disorganized and unclear he was. He did not teach in any lecture and students presented for the entire duration. The rubrics were provided late, and they were quite ambiguous. We received limited feedback throughout the course and grades seemed random.

Seems like he created a class structure which allowed him to be as lazy as possible. Every lecture we would have 3 presentations take up the full allotted 3hrs, usually about 10 mins over. Irshad doesnt lecture, and usually wouldnt have lecture slides.

Issues 1. Asking students to do 5 presentations, each with a different group of students is unrealistic. 2. Lecture routinely ran over time and assignment instructions were ambiguous. 3. Lectures consisted of 3 student presentations, with no actual teaching. Overall I'd suggest restructuring the class to include teaching, otherwise perhaps quit.

He is a nice guy and you can tell he is smart. Will he teach you anything, no. Be prepared to learn nothing. He doesn't teach, he makes the students present all class. He give way too many assignments worth like 3% or 2% but his criteria is unclear and he makes it up as he goes. And you literally have to force him to give you feedback or a grade!

worst prof at sfu... unprepared, has no idea what he's talking about.  assignments are vague and have no criteria, takes forever to mark. teaches case style but doesn't provide any supporting tools to help analyze the case. extremely slow to reply to e-mails. If you send him an e-mail after class, he won't reply until the day before the assignment

It does not seem like a 400 level course, more like a continuation of 237. Final paper, but no final. Very little amount of readings and work. Not much is learned. Most lectures are taken up by weekly presentations with topics and discussion that may or may not interest you. Marks fairly according to criteria although he takes his time.
